entry.title: Functional Programming – The New Frontier?
entry.content:
Functional programming languages seem to gain resurgence in popularity recently, languages like Elixir, Elm, Clojure, Scala and Haskell are gaining mind share in web development.

Is it another programming fad that will come and go? Maybe, but some very wise people are talking about Functional languages and they raise good points.

  • Moore’s Law is stagnating failing
  • Multi-core architectures are promoted over CPU clock speed
  • Concurrency is hard on OOP languages

Robert C. Martin (Uncle Bob) has a great presentation on the subject, see below. Dave Thomas strongly advised learning Functional Programming on the Code Newbie Podcast (@ 1h 13 minutes).

I have been curious about Function Programming for a while now, and it sounds like now is a good time to approach the subject.

entry.title: Update Ruby Version Definitions in Rbenv
entry.content:
I was starting a new project and was looking to update my Ruby version to latest version that is supported on Heroku, but alas the most recent version of Ruby in my rbenv was:

rbenv install --list

=> 2.2.0-dev

To update the Ruby version definitions:

  1. brew upgrade
  2. brew upgrade ruby-build

Installing Ruby 2.2.2

rbenv install 2.2.2

rbenv global 2.2.2  # or rbenv local 2.2.2

rbenv rehash

All done!

entry.title: Installing the Scheme Language Compiler on OSX
entry.content:
When you go looking for a Scheme compiler / interpreter it’s easy to get overwhelmed, there are over 70 Scheme implementations on the Scheme Wiki. Which one do you pick?

The answer is Chicken Scheme, as passionately endorsed by Aaron Patterson is a practical and portable scheme system that is actively maintained and compiles down to C.

The simplest way to install a Scheme compiler / interpreter on a Mac OSX

  1. Install Homebrew
  2. Type in the Terminal: brew install chicken
  3. Profit!

Hello World Example

Type in the hello world program:

;;; hello-world.scm

(print "Hello World, From Scheme")

Run it using the Scheme interpreter

csi -s hello-world.scm

Compile it to an executable binary

csc hello-world.scm

Running the executable binary

./hello-world

Bonus

There is a nice Scheme language package for the Atom Editor.

entry.title: The DOM is Too Slow - Achieving 60fps on the mobile web
entry.content:
The DOM is too slow.

via – 60fps on the mobile web — Flipboard Engineering.

An interesting take by the Flipboard team on bringing mobile web rendering performance to native application level. While the technical achievement of the react-canvas is impressive it does come with many caveats especially in accessibility and SEO in mind.

This reminds me of the tradeoffs of using Flash based websites back in the day, improving interactivity and design but hurting accessibility of basic features such as copying text or using screen readers. But I can see great potential of using something like react-canvas with Cordova or PhoneGap to create mobile apps using web technologies.

I hope that this will steer the Mobile Browser makers to implement hardware accelerated DOM rendering on mobile.

entry.title: Mobile Safari Does Not Render Large Images
entry.content:
Came across this issue today – really large images would not render in Mobile Safari on iPhone or iPad. If the image is too big iOS ignores the asset.

The problem is due to the iOS Resource Limits, which states:

The maximum size for decoded GIF, PNG, and TIFF images is 3 megapixels for devices with less than 256 MB RAM and 5 megapixels for devices with greater or equal than 256 MB RAM. That is, ensure that width * height ≤ 3 * 1024 * 1024 for devices with less than 256 MB RAM. Note that the decoded size is far larger than the encoded size of an image.

The solution is to resize your image dimensions to fit into the sizes that Apple Mobile Safari can decode.

via – Safari Web Content Guide

entry.title: Acqui-hire economics
entry.content:
The rule of thumb is that only one or two out of every ten startups will succeed as a business. Only one out of a hundred will be a real home run. With the rest, the ideas like Color that seem great on paper but fail to catch on in the real world, an acqui-hire is often the best solution for all parties.

It seems weird compared to any other industry, but good engineers are a commodity in silicone valley, it’s kind of a win win.

via Why Apple acquiring Color makes sense in Silicon Valley: the strange logic of the acqui-hire - The Verge
